# Definitions
[italic]These definitions are used throughout the rest of Marine Law.[/italic]
[color=#00CBFE][bold]Commanding Officer[/bold][/color] - An official UNMC Commanding Officer. - Anything with the words [color=#00CBFE][bold]Commanding Officer[/bold][/color] only applies to whitelisted Commanding Officers. These rights cannot be transferred.
\n
[color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color] - The current [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color] of an operation. - Transferable to a new [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color], per the [textlink="Chain of Command" link="RMCCommandChain"].
If the [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color] is rendered incapable of command [bold]temporarily[/bold], the [color=#90EE90][bold]Duty Officer[/bold][/color] inherits [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color] rights, but should the [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color] return, they are still the [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color]. This includes but is not limited to:
- Prolonged communications outage. - The [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color] deploying in the field.
If the [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color] is rendered [bold]permanently[/bold] incapable of command, the next in the [textlink="Chain of Command" link="RMCCommandChain"] becomes the [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color], rather than a [color=#90EE90][bold]Duty Officer[/bold][/color]. This includes but is not limited to: - The [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color] is relieved of duty due to [bold]arrest[/bold] or [bold]mutiny[/bold]. - The [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color] becoming [bold]unrevivable[/bold].
\n
[color=#90EE90][bold]Duty Officer[/bold][/color] - The ranking officer in the [textlink="Chain of Command" link="RMCCommandChain"] who, in the temporary absence of the [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color], is placed in command of the warship. - Unless explicitly stated otherwise, the [color=#90EE90][bold]Duty Officer[/bold][/color] is interchangeable with, and inherits the rights of [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color] in this case.
\n
[color=#8B0000][bold]Chief MP[/bold][/color] - The Chief of Military Police, assigned to the warship. - Only transferable to a [bold]Warden[/bold] by the [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color], if another [color=#ff000d][bold]MP[/bold][/color] is appointed to be the acting [bold]Warden[/bold].
\n
[color=#ff000d][bold]MP[/bold][/color] - Military Police, including personnel validly deputized by the [color=#00CBFE][bold]Commanding Officer[/bold][/color], who deal with Marine Law.
\n
[bold]Officer[/bold] - A person who is a Commissioned Officer. These rights cannot be transferred.
\n
[bold]Department heads[/bold] - A person who is responsible for an entire department, which includes the [bold]Chief Engineer[/bold], [bold]Chief Medical Officer[/bold], [bold]Auxiliary Support Officer[/bold], [bold]Quartermaster[/bold], [color=#8B0000][bold]Chief MP[/bold][/color].
\n
[bold]CIC Personnel[/bold] - Standard personnel whose main duties are within CIC. This includes the [color=#00CBFE][bold]Commanding Officer[/bold][/color], [bold]Executive Officer[/bold], and [bold]Staff Officers[/bold].
\n
[bold]Aiding, abetting, conspiring[/bold] - Assisting others in committing a crime, directly or indirectly, encouraging them to commit one (including bribery), conspiring or attempting to commit a crime will be treated as having committed that crime with regards to punishment.
\n
[bold]Lawful Orders[/bold] - Personnel are required to follow all lawful orders from their superiors and are NOT-required to follow unlawful orders. - If personnel are refusing to follow an order, they must state why they believe it would break Marine Law, making it an unlawful order. - Valid NJPs are not unlawful orders in the case of neglected duties.
\n
[bold]Riot equipment[/bold] - Flashbangs. - Teargas. - Riot shotguns with beanbag rounds. - Riot shields and armor. - Riot grenade launchers.
\n
[bold]FOB[/bold] - The Forward Operating Base. - Designated by the [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color]. It is a reinforced area, usually being the primary landing zone. - FOBs do not have to be placed adjacent to a landing zone. However, the primary landing zone itself must at least be properly defended and guarded.
\n
[bold]Area of Operations (AO)[/bold] - The area of operations is the broad location where personnel are being deployed to conduct an operation.
\n
[bold]Secure Areas[/bold] - Must be designated by the [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color] or staff officers. It is a reinforced area, where there has been no recent combat or threats. - The [bold]FOB[/bold] is usually a secure area until it is attacked, for example. - The [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color] or any [bold]CIC Personnel[/bold] at any point may designate an area no longer secure. - Areas that have been recently attacked are presumed no longer secure, and should be reported for safety.
\n
[bold]Field Hospital[/bold] - Must be designated by the [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color] or [bold]Chief Medical Officer[/bold]. It is a reinforced area, where there has been no recent combat or threats. - It is the only area aside from the [bold]FOB[/bold] that the [bold]Chief Medical Officer[/bold] or [color=#008000][bold]Commander[/bold][/color] may give permission to doctors and nurse to move to. - It must be designated as a [bold]Secure Area.[/bold]
\n
[bold]Alert Levels[/bold] - Code [bold][color=lightgreen]Green[/color][/bold]: All clear. - Code [bold][color=lightblue]Blue[/color][/bold]: Potentially hostile activity on board. - Code [bold][color=red]Red[/color][/bold]: There is an immediate threat to the ship or it's crew. Examples of usage include; AI Core Security issue, biohazard containment breach, general quarters. Distress beacon, evacuation, and usage of sentry systems authorized. - Code [bold][color=black]Delta[/color][/bold]: Immediately applies if the warship hull has a major breach by intruders. An order of evacuation, self destruction, or hold of the warship will be made at this time.
\n
[color=#ffa500][bold]Provost Marshal Office[/bold][/color] - Hold significant weight on how Marine Law is handled in their operational areas. - In the event that Marine Law is being mishandled aboard a UNMC warship or within the AO of a UNMC warship, [color=#ffa500][bold]Provost Marshal Office[/bold][/color] may see fit to dispatch personnel. - Members of the [color=#ffa500][bold]Provost Marshal Office[/bold][/color] obey only their direct superiors and are not beholden to the Marine Chain of Command. - Provost [bold]Marshals[/bold] are not required to follow Marine Law. - Provost [bold]Inspectors[/bold] and above are the final word on Marine Law in their AO. - Provost [bold]Advisors[/bold] do not hold any direct authority themselves, however they are expected to ensure Marine Law is correctly handled.
